feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.title: Frost Advisory issued January 26 at 9:32PM PST until January 27 at 9:00AM PST by NWS San Francisco CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Frost Advisory, temperatures as low as 32 will result in frost formation. For the Freeze Watch, near-freezing temperatures as low as 32 possible.
* WHERE...The East Bay and San Francisco Bay Shoreline, Monterey Bay and the Big Sur Coast, Santa Cruz Mountains, and North Bay Interior Valleys.
* WHEN...For the Frost Advisory, from 1 AM to 9 AM PST Monday. For the Freeze Watch, from late Monday night through Thursday morning.
* IMPACTS...Frost and freeze conditions could kill crops, other sensitive vegetation and possibly damage unprotected outdoor plumbing. Cold conditions will be hazardous to sensitive populations such as unhoused individuals. Cold Conditions can lead to hypothermia with prolonged exposure.
entry.cap:areaDesc: North Bay Interior Valleys; San Francisco Bay Shoreline; East Bay Interior Valleys; Santa Cruz Mountains; East Bay Hills; Northern Monterey Bay; Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast

cap:parameter.value: FROST ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 1 AM TO 9 AM PST MONDAY... ...FREEZE WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM LATE MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY MORNING

entry.title: Freeze Warning issued January 26 at 9:32PM PST until January 27 at 9:00AM PST by NWS San Francisco CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Freeze Warning, sub-freezing temperatures as low as 28 expected. For the Freeze Watch, sub-freezing temperatures as low as 30 possible.
* WHERE...Interior Central Coast, Santa Clara Valley and Eastern Hills.
* WHEN...For the Freeze Warning, from 1 AM to 9 AM PST Monday. For the Freeze Watch, from late Monday night through Thursday morning.
* IMPACTS...Cold conditions will be hazardous to sensitive populations such as unhoused individuals. Cold Conditions can lead to hypothermia with prolonged exposure. Frost and freeze conditions could kill crops, other sensitive vegetation and possibly damage unprotected outdoor plumbing.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The city of San Jose will likely dip into the mid 30s.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued January 26 at 8:54PM PST until January 26 at 11:00PM PST by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...Southwestern Santa Barbara County, including the south coast, from Point Conception to Santa Barbara City.
* WHEN...Until 1100 PM PST.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Water over roadways.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 854 PM PST, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated heavy rain. Overflowing poor drainage areas have already caused minor flooding in the advisory area. Up to 0.3 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts of 0.2 to 0.5 inches are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Santa Barbara, Lompoc, Santa Ynez, Point Conception, Solvang, Refugio State Beach, Highway 101 through Gaviota State Park, Goleta, Lake Cachuma, Highway 154 over San Marcos Pass, Santa Barbara Airport, and Mission Hills. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued January 26 at 6:45PM HST until January 26 at 10:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
FFWHFO
The National Weather Service in Honolulu has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... The island of Oahu in Honolulu County
* Until 1000 PM HST.
* At 645 PM HST, radar indicated heavy rain over eastern Oahu, with the heaviest rain falling from Kaaawa to Manoa. Rain was falling at a rate of 2 to 3 inches per hour. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by heavy rain.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Flooding in drainages, streams, rivers, roads, properties, and other low-lying areas. Public road closures possible in some areas. Landslides are possible in steep terrain.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Honolulu, Waipio, Waiahole, Waikane, Kahaluu, Ahuimanu, Aiea, Pearl City, Kaaawa, Halawa, Mililani, Moanalua, Punaluu, Salt Lake, Kaneohe, Wahiawa, Kalihi, Wheeler Field, Hauula and Kaneohe Marine Base.

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued January 26 at 8:15PM PST until January 26 at 11:00PM PST by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
entry.summary:
At 815 PM PST, local law enforcement reported flooding along the PCH produced by heavy rain across the warned area. While not immediately likely, a life threatening debris flow will be possible.
HAZARD...Debris flows caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Law enforcement reported.
IMPACT...Mud, rock, and debris flows will impact drainages, roads, and residences in and directly below the burn area.
Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Malibu, Malibu Creek State Park and Malibu Canyon and Los Virgenes Roads through the Santa Monica Mountains.
A 0.39 inch per hour rainfall rate has been reported around Pepperdine and higher rainfall rates are likely occuring.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued January 26 at 5:06PM HST until January 27 at 6:00AM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT FOR KAUAI OAHU MOLOKAI MAUI LANAI NIIHAU AND KAHOOLAWE THROUGH TONIGHT...
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.
* WHERE...Kauai, Oahu, Maui, Molokai, Lanai, Kahoolawe, and Niihau.
* WHEN...Through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...Flood prone roads and other low lying areas may be closed due to elevated runoff and overflowing streams. Urban areas may receive more significant flooding and property damage due to rapid runoff.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - A trough developing near Oahu will merge with a front overnight and move slowly eastward. An upper level trough will trigger heavy showers and thunderstorms along the trough, bringing the threat for flash flooding, especially over windward areas. The flood threat will decrease during the day on Monday.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued January 26 at 6:01PM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
Strong east to southeasterly winds will continue across the the Matanuska Valley through tonight as a potent storm system moves through the region. Winds 20 to 35 mph with gusts to 60 mph are possible for the Knik River Valley and Palmer. For areas west of the Parks and Glenn Highway Interchange, including Wasilla, winds 15 to 25 mph with gusts to 40 mph are possible.
There will likely be multiple peaks and lulls in the overall strength of the winds through Monday, but they will largely remain gusty the entire time.

cap:parameter.value: STRONG WINDS ACROSS THE MATANUSKA VALLEY THROUGH MONDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued January 26 at 6:01PM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
A frontal system moving into Prince William Sound early Monday morning will result in an increase in south to southwesterly winds and colder air moving up Cook Inlet on Monday. Sustained winds of 20 to 35 mph with gusts 40 to 60 mph are possible from Homer north to Nikiski early Monday morning through late Monday night. Wave heights will also build across Kachemak Bay through the day Monday, leading to rough surf around Homer Spit.
People are urged to secure loose objects that could be blown around or damaged by the wind. Prepare for the possibility of power outages. Use caution if you must drive.

cap:parameter.value: STRONG SOUTHERLY WIND GUSTS TO DEVELOP ACROSS THE WESTERN KENAI PENINSULA AND KACHEMAK BAY MONDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued January 26 at 6:01PM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
Strong southeasterly wind gusts and periods of moderate snow will continue for elevations above 1800 feet through the rest of this evening, including the Glen Alps area of the Anchorage Hillside and the Arctic Valley and Upper Hiland Road areas of Eagle River. Temperatures will continue to cool overnight. Winds may gust as high as 60 to 70 mph through the rest of this evening, switching southerly after midnight and decreasing to around 50 mph through Monday morning. The combination of snow and wind will lead to significant drifting and blowing snow with significantly reduced visibility.
Gusty winds of 45 to 55 mph from the south to southwest will also be possible as another surge of winds move across the Anchorage Bowl, particularly for west Anchorage late morning to around noon.

cap:parameter.value: GUSTY WINDS AND SNOW TO CONTINUE FOR THE UPPER HILLSIDE OF ANCHORAGE AND HIGHER ELEVATIONS OF EAGLE RIVER THROUGH MONDAY MORNING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued January 26 at 3:46PM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
Widespread snow showers will move into the Pribilof Islands as a compact low moves into the area between Monday and Monday night. Widespread snow showers will move into the area as the low approaches. Snow combined with winds gusting as high as 40 to 50 mph could cause intermittent periods of significantly reduced visibility and blowing snow. Conditions will improve late Monday night into Tuesday morning as winds subside and as snow showers become more isolated.
Use caution while traveling and be prepared for rapidly changing winds and visibility as this system approaches on Monday evening.

entry.summary: The prolonged warming event across the Interior, including rainfall on ice, will end Monday afternoon and evening as a strong arctic cold front moves in with blustery southwest winds and snow showers. entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued January 26 at 12:20PM AKST until January 28 at 3:00AM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...SNOW RETURNS TO THE KLONDIKE...
.Incoming front will push a long fetch of moisture over the panhandle. Due to cold air already in place, the passing moisture will fall as snow beginning tonight. Moderate snow will begin mainly after midnight with the snow lasting through Monday. A lull in the rates is possible Monday afternoon but rates should pick back up Monday evening. Snow will continue into Tuesday but rates will greatly lighten up due to the front exiting the area and the panhandle going into a more onshore/showery pattern.
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 6 to 9 inches. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph.
* WHERE...Klondike Highway, mainly from mile marker 8 to the border.
* WHEN...From midnight tonight to 3 AM AKST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snowfall rates will be up to 0.5 to 1 inch per hour from midnight to midday Monday. Snowfall rates will decrease Monday afternoon before picking back up to near 0.5 to 1 inch per hour again late Monday evening. Light snow will linger through Tuesday but rates will greatly diminish after 3 AM.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued January 26 at 2:53PM EST by NWS Morristown TN
entry.summary:
Precipitation will move in tonight with snow likely. Due to the recent warmer ground temperatures, how much snow accumulates is uncertain. Some areas will likely see no accumulation while others could see up to 1 inch. It's also possible that a few isolated areas see up to 2 inches. The greatest chance of accumulation will be across the higher elevations.
The light snowfall may produce some snow covered roadways by early morning, especially secondary roads, bridges and overpasses, and higher elevations. Drive with caution and slow down.
Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio and other local media for further details or updates.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued January 26 at 10:35AM AKST until January 27 at 9:00AM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
Flooding continues along the Anchor River due to an ice jam and runoff from heavy rainfall that fell over the weekend.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...the Anchor River near Anchor Point Road downstream of the Sterling Highway and the Anchor River State Recreation Area, with additional flooding along the Sterling Highway near mile marker 160 and 161 (Blackwater Bend).
* WHEN...Until 900 AM AKST Monday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. Streams continue to rise due to excess runoff from rainfall. Low-water crossings are inundated with water and may not be passable. Overflowing poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10 AM AKST, Emergency Management reported that severe flooding continues along the Anchor River and conditions remain unchanged. Flooding continued along the Anchor River near the Old Sterling Highway and along the Sterling Highway near mile marker 160 and 161 (Blackwater Bend). Flooding is ongoing on the Anchor River. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued January 25 at 11:14PM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
SABAFC
The following message is transmitted at the request of the Valdez Avalanche Center.
...THE VALDEZ AVALANCHE CENTER HAS ISSUED AN AVALANCHE WARNING FOR THE FOLLOWING AREAS: VALDEZ, THOMPSON PASS FROM 6AM SUNDAY THROUGH 6AM MONDAY...
* WHAT... The backcountry avalanche danger is HIGH. Very
dangerous avalanche conditions exist.
* WHERE...For the mountains surrounding the Valdez and Thompson Pass area.
* WHEN...In effect from Sunday 6:00 AM through Monday 6:00 AM AKST.
* IMPACTS...Continued heavy snowfall along with strong winds and the possibility for rain on snow at low elevations will create widespread areas of unstable snow. Natural avalanches will become likely Sunday morning and human triggered avalanches will be very likely. Avalanche debris may run into valley bottoms.
* PRECAUTIONARY / PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...Travel in avalanche terrain is NOT recommended. Backcountry travelers should stay off of...and out from underneath slopes steeper than 30 degrees. Avalanches may run long distances.
Similar avalanche danger may exist outside the coverage area of this or any avalanche center.
For more information visit alaskasnow.org/valdez

entry.title: Avalanche Advisory issued January 25 at 5:37PM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
SABAFC
The following message is transmitted at the request of the Hatcher Pass Avalanche Center.
...THE HATCHER PASS AVALANCHE CENTER HAS ISSUED AN AVALANCHE WARNING FOR HATCHER PASS...
* WHAT...The backcountry avalanche danger is HIGH. Very dangerous avalanche conditions exist.
* WHERE...From Mile 10 to Independence Mine, including Gold Mint and Archangel Valley.
* WHEN...Now through Monday 7:00 AM AKST.
* IMPACTS...Strong winds, intense precipitation, and a lowering freezing level could bring an additional 12 inches of new snow to elevations above 1500 feet. Large to very large widespread natural avalanche activity is expected.
* PRECAUTIONARY / PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...Travel in avalanche terrain is not recommended. Backcountry travelers should stay off of...and out from underneath slopes steeper than 30 degrees. Avalanches may run long distances to valley bottoms. Avoid avalanche terrain.
Similar avalanche danger may exist outside the coverage area of this or any avalanche center.
For more information visit hpavalanche.org.

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued January 24 at 9:29AM MST by NWS Pueblo CO
entry.summary:
ESFPUB
This statement is primarily for the Arkansas River in Fremont, Pueblo, Crowley, Otero and Bent Counties.
This statement is valid from Jan 24 to Jan 30, 2025.
Warming temperatures has led to the break up and movement of river ice. Accumulating river ice at bridges, river bends, or other channel constrictions may lead to jamming and elevated river levels.
Flooding is not expected at this time. However, elevated river levels from ice jams can occur rapidly and with little notice.
Please report any flooding to local law enforcement and emergency management, and heed caution when near the Arkansas River.
...ADDITIONAL INFORMATION...
For the latest weather information and alert notifications for southeast and south-central Colorado, visit our web site at weather.gov/pub
For more hydrologic information including graphs of probabilistic river outlooks and forecasts, visit the National Water Prediction Service page at water.noaa.gov
entry.cap:areaDesc: Bent, CO; Crowley, CO; Fremont, CO; Otero, CO; Pueblo, CO

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued January 24 at 10:25AM EST by NWS Northern Indiana
entry.summary:
ESFIWX
Favorable conditions for possible river ice jams are expected over the next week.
Bitterly cold temperatures have created some ice formation on area rivers and with slight warming later this weekend and into early next week may make for favorable conditions for ice jams on area rivers and tributaries. River ice spotters are asked to report any ice jams or ice jam flooding. Any ice jam that develops will have the potential to cause rises on area rivers with little to no warning and isolated areas of flooding are possible.
This outlook means that elevated water levels and potential impacts are possible, but not yet certain. Persons along area rivers should continue to monitor the latest forecasts over the next week.
